slidelink.displaytext: What and How Do We Define Stem Cells
What Happens in a Flow Cytometer?
Why Look at FSC v. SSC
Differentiation Potentials in ALDH Bright fraction

search.slidetext: stem cells 101 doris taylor, phd, facc, fahaco-director, biorepository core cctrn
what are stem cells and how do we define them with markers in cctrn in 2014? doris taylor phd, faha, faccfor the cctrn brc

stem cells vs. progenitor cells stem cells – cells that can self-renew and differentiate into multiple lineages totipotent – can give rise to all three developmental lineages (endoderm, ectoderm and mesoderm) es cells, ips cellspluripotent – can give rise to two or more developmental lineages (hscs, bmcs)multipotent – can give rise to multiple cell types usually within a lineage (mscs)
mesenchymal stem cell hematopoietic stem cell totipotent

stem cells vs. progenitor cells stem cells – cells that can self-renew and differentiate into multiple lineages totipotent – can give rise to all three developmental lineages (endoderm, ectoderm and mesoderm) es cells, ips cellspluripotent – can give rise to two or more developmental lineages (hscs, bmcs)multipotent – can give rise to multiple cell types usually within a lineage (mscs)
mesenchymal stem cell hematopoietic stem cell totipotent

embryonic vs. ips cells embryonic stem cells – derived from fertilized egg blastocyst inner cell mass (usually at 8-150 cell stage)ips cells – derived from skin bone marrow or blood cells – use 1-4 viruses, genes or mirs to push the cells back to an embryonic stem cell-like fateips cells are marked epigenetically (dna is methylated or demethylated to turn certain genes off or on) so they have the advantages of es cells but the disadvantages of adult scs.
mesenchymal stem cell hematopoietic stem cell totipotent

embryonic vs. ips cells embryonic stem cells – derived from fertilized egg blastocyst inner cell mass (usually at 8-150 cell stage)ips cells – derived from skin bone marrow or blood cells – use 1-4 viruses, genes or mirs to push the cells back to an embryonic stem cell-like fateips cells are marked epigenetically (dna is methylated or demethylated to turn certain genes off or on) so they have the advantages of es cells but the disadvantages of adult scs.
gives rise to blood cells (bmc) pluripotent
bone marrow or fat stromal cell
gives rise to blood cells (bmc) pluripotent
bone marrow or fat stromal cell
mesenchymal stem cell sources bone marrow (stromal cells)adipose tissueheart stromaalmost any other tissue stromablood (rare)decline with aging 1:10,000 – 1:10,000,000

progenitor cells – more limited differentiation capacity usually committed to a lineage (e.g., hematopoietic progenitor, endothelial progenitor, cardiac progenitor…) sometimes used just to differentiate by name from a stem cell for non-scientific reasons (mesodermal progenitor vs msc for ip reasons) stem cells vs. progenitor cells

a stem cell journey creation (cardiac often during development progenitor) proliferation in response to signalmobilization/migration (inflammation, toward a signal chemokines) commitment to a lineage (cardiosphere)differentiation (immature into a given cell type cardiocyte)maturation of that cell type (mature cardiocyte)

notes about stem cell populations every population is unique to the individualevery single or double marker population is heterogeneousmultiple markers are needed to narrow down a populationdifferent labs use different definitions of a given stem or progenitor cell (eg epcs)cells are dynamic – they change over time

how do we define cells?phenotype: flow cytometrycluster of differentiation (cd) flow cytometry: characterize and separate cells based on their physical and chemical characteristics. provide multiparameter analyses based on the measurement of visible and fluorescent light emission produced by fluorescent-labeled antibodies that bind to cell-associated molecules.

what happens in a flow cytometer? cells in suspension flow single file pasta focused laser where they scatter light and emit fluorescence that is filtered, collectedand converted to digitized values that are stored in a file which can then be read by specialized software. interrogation interrogation fluidics fluidics electronics electronics interpretation interpretation
side scatter fscdetector fscdetector collectionlens collectionlens sscdetector sscdetector laser beam laser beam fsc ssc fsc ssc

why look at fsc v. ssc since fsc ~ size and ssc ~ internal structure, a correlated measurement between them can allow for differentiation of cell types in a heterogenous cell population fsc ssc fsc ssc lymphocytes lymphocytes monocytes monocytes granulocytes granulocytes rbcs, debris,dead cells rbcs, debris,dead cells

cd markers have numbers cd1-cd350were named by the first inter­na­tional workshop on human leukocyte dif­fer­en­ti­ation antigens.many have names that were assigned prior to the cd numbers: cd117 = c-kit cd309 = vegfr2/kdr/ly-73/flk-1
cd45-cd133+cd117+ (c-kit+)cd45-cd117+cd45-kdr+cd45-cd105+ hematopoietic stem cell markers
hematopoieticprogenitors cd34+ cd90+ cd133+ cd45+ cd117+cd45dim cd34+cd45dim cd34+ cd117+cd45dim cd34+ cd133+

cd34 quantification following ishage gating strategy (sutherland et al 1996) cd45 events cd45 events lkc (10e9 /l) x cd34 events x1000 cd34 is expressed on ~1-4% of bm cells ~0.1-1% of umbilical cord blood cells.~0.03- 0.1% in pb

differentiated stem cells once in place stem cells will likely commit, differentiate, and mature depending on the environment in which they find themselvesarchitecture (2-d vs 3-d)mechanics (stiffness)biology (growth factors)chemistry (drugs or media)
mesenchymal stem cell differentiation
cardiac stem cell differentiation proliferate commit differentiate mature integrate
heart differentiation markers stem cell (flk,cd106)cardioblast (gata-4, hand)cardiocyte (a-actinin)mature cardiocyte(b-myosin, a-myosin,ctni)

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Figure 1. Common methods of “EPC” culture. Culture of colony forming unitHill cells (CFU-Hill, Method A, scale bar=100 um), includes a 5-day process wherein nonadherent peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PB-MNCs) give rise to the colony. Circulating angiogenic cells (CAC, Method B, scale bar=200 um) are the adherent mononuclear cells of a 4- to 7-day culture of PB-MNCs. CAC cultures typically do not display colony formation. Endothelial colony forming cells (ECFCs, Method B, scale bar=400 um) are derived from adherent PB-MNCs cultured for 6 to 21 days in endothelial conditions, and colonies display a cobblestone morphology. Only the ECFC progeny form blood vessels de novo in vivo. Images were collected using a Zeiss Axiovert 2 inverted microscope with 10×/0.25Ph1 CP-ACROMAT (CFU-EC), 32×/0.40Ph1 LD-ACROSTIGMAT (CAC), or 5× CP-ACHROMAT/0.12Ph0 (ECFC) objectives. Images were acquired using a SPOT RT color camera (Diagnostic Instruments) with the manufacturer’s software. Images cropped and scale bars added in Adobe Photoshop version 8.0. Modified from Prater DN et al. Working hypothesis to redefine endothelial progenitor cells. Leukemia. 2007;21:1142.
Hematopoietic
14-21 days

So visually, you can see that individuals can be divided into two groups: cases and controls. The red lines indicate those who showed an improvement (cases). The same is true for LVEF and also VO2 max.
The results of the analyses of the primary outcomes are as follows.

Need p value
Here you can see the number of cases where benefits were seen in one, two, or three outcomes.
